title: Risk of silica dust exposure for Chch construction team
text:
Risk of silica dust exposure for Chch construction team 
Saturday 18 Jul 2015 7:24 a.m. 
Construction workers involved in the Christchurch earthquake rebuild are being exposed to dangerous silica dust because they're unaware of the dangers, a study says. 
Silica dust causes the lung disease silicosis, marked by inflammation and scarring of the lungs and WorkSafe NZ says the study it commissioned, amid fears the dust could be a problem during the rebuild, shows a lot of people don't know enough about the risks. 
The main findings show a lack of knowledge of the risk of silica dust, a lack of efficient dust suppression and a large number of construction workers not using respiratory protection. 
The workers are being exposed to levels exceeding national and international standards, says WorkSafe's Professor Bill Glass. 
"The main sources of excessive exposure have been shown to occur when using concrete polishers and grinders." 
Concrete, drilling, crushing and cutting Linea board were also exposing workers to high levels of silica dust, he said. 
Moves needed to be taken to reduce the level of exposure and WorkSafe and construction companies were now reviewing what could be done, he said. 
NZN
